q: What is trigger finger?
a: Trigger finger is a condition that affects the tendons in the hand, making it difficult to bend the affected finger or thumb. It can cause pain, stiffness, and a clicking sensation.

q: What are the symptoms of trigger finger?
a: Symptoms of trigger finger can include pain at the base of the affected finger or thumb, stiffness, clicking sensation, and difficulty in bending or straightening the finger or thumb.

q: How is trigger finger diagnosed?
i: If you think you may have trigger finger.
a: If you think you may have trigger finger, it is recommended to see your GP. They will examine your hand and advise you on appropriate treatments.

q: What causes trigger finger?
a: Trigger finger is caused by inflammation and swelling of the tendon or sheath in the hand. Factors that may increase the risk include age, gender, and certain medical conditions.

q: Is trigger finger more common in women?
a: Yes, trigger finger is more common in women.

q: Can trigger finger be treated without intervention?
a: In some cases, trigger finger may get better without treatment. However, if left untreated, it can lead to permanent bending of the affected finger or thumb.

q: What are the treatment options for trigger finger?
a: Treatment options for trigger finger include rest, medication (such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), splinting, steroid injection, and surgery.

q: Is surgery the only option for trigger finger?
a: Surgery is usually considered as a last resort if other treatments have failed. It can have a high success rate, but recovery time may be needed, especially for manual job workers.

q: Can trigger finger affect children?
a: Trigger finger is uncommon in children, but it can occur. It may affect their ability to straighten their thumb, but it usually improves without treatment by age 3.

q: Is trigger finger painful in children?
a: Trigger finger in children is rarely painful.

q: What is trigger finger?
a: Trigger finger is a condition that affects one or more of the hand's tendons, making it difficult to bend the affected finger or thumb.

q: What are the symptoms of trigger finger?
a: Symptoms of trigger finger can include pain at the base of the affected finger or thumb when you move it or press on it, stiffness or clicking when you move the affected finger or thumb, and difficulty bending or straightening the finger.

q: What causes trigger finger?
a: Trigger finger occurs when there is inflammation and swelling in the tendon or sheath, causing the tendon to get caught in the sheath and resulting in difficulty moving the finger or thumb.

q: How is trigger finger treated?
a: Treatment options for trigger finger include rest, medication, splinting, steroid injections, and surgery, depending on the severity of the condition.

q: Is trigger finger more common in certain populations?
a: Trigger finger is more common in women, people over 40 years old, and those with certain medical conditions. It is also associated with Dupuytren's contracture and long-term conditions like diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis.

q: Can trigger finger improve without treatment?
a: In some cases, trigger finger may improve without treatment. However, without treatment, there is a risk of the affected finger or thumb becoming permanently bent.

q: What are the treatment options for trigger finger?
a: Treatment options for trigger finger include rest, medication, splinting, steroid injections, and surgery.

q: Is trigger finger common in children?
a: Trigger finger is uncommon in children, but it can sometimes occur in young children. It is usually not painful and often resolves on its own by age 3 without treatment.

q: Can trigger finger surgery be effective?
a: Surgery for trigger finger can be up to 100% effective. However, it is usually considered as a last resort when other treatments have failed.

q: How long does recovery take after trigger finger surgery?
a: Recovery after trigger finger surgery may take 2 to 4 weeks, but the duration can vary depending on the individual and their job requirements.
